questions.text: At the midaxillary line, the inferior border of the right lung typically corresponds to which rib level?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 8th

 

Explanation:

  • The lower border of each lung lies two ribs higher than the parietal pleural reflection.
  • It crosses the eighth rib in the midaxillary line.

 

Lung markings

Anterior border:

Right lung

Left lung

Corresponds to the anterior margin of the pleura up to the level of the 6th costal cartilage.

Corresponds to the anterior margin of the pleura up to the level of the 4th costal cartilage. (Option A )

Curves downwards and medially to reach the sixth costal cartilage to form the cardiac notch.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presents with sharp, stabbing pain in the right upper abdomen for 2 weeks. The pain is aggravated by deep breathing and movement, especially when bending or twisting. There is tenderness over the right costal margin, but no signs of gastrointestinal distress, fever, or abdominal distension. His medical history is unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Subcostal neuralgia

Explanation:

  • Subcostal neuralgia is caused by irritation or compression of the T12 (subcostal) nerve, which provides sensory innervation to the skin of the upper abdomen below the ribcage.
  • It typically presents with sharp, localized pain along the costal margin, especially aggravated by deep breathing or movement (such as twisting or bending).
  • The pain can be unilateral, as seen in this patient.
  • The absence of gastrointestinal symptoms (like nausea, vomiting, or changes in bowel habits), along with localized tenderness over the right costal margin, supports the diagnosis of subcostal neuralgia.
  • Subcostal neuralgia can be caused by various factors, including nerve compression, inflammation, or irritation of the intercostal nerves.
  • It may also follow trauma, surgical procedures (especially abdominal surgeries), or infections.
  • The condition can sometimes occur without any obvious underlying cause.
  • It is typically managed with pain relief, such as non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), and physical therapy to help relieve nerve compression.
  • The intercostal nerves are part of the somatic nervous system and arise from the ventral rami of the T1-T11 spinal nerves.
  • The 12th spinal nerve does not contribute to the intercostal nerves, but rather forms the subcostal nerve.
  • Origin:
    • The intercostal nerves are derived from the ventral rami of the thoracic spinal nerves (T1-T11).
  • Course:
    • These nerves travel along the intercostal spaces between the ribs, passing laterally and then anteriorly toward the sternum.
  • They travel in the costal groove on the inferior aspect of each rib, along with the intercostal artery and vein.
  • The nerves are positioned in the neurovascular bundle along the inferior border of each rib, with the vein superior, the artery in the middle, and the nerve inferior.
  • Branches:
    • Each intercostal nerve gives off several branches:
      • Lateral cutaneous branch: Provides sensory innervation to the skin of the lateral chest and upper abdomen.
      • Anterior cutaneous branch: Supplies the skin over the anterior chest wall.
      • Muscular branches: Innervate the intercostal muscles, transversus thoracis, and sometimes the serratus anterior muscle.
      • Rami communicantes: Connect the intercostal nerve to the sympathetic trunk.
  • Function:
    • Motor: To the intercostal muscles (which aid in respiration).
    • Sensory: To the skin of the chest, abdomen, and parts of the back.
    • Sympathetic: To the sweat glands and blood vessels in the region.​​​​​​​

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​T12 (Subcostal Nerve): The T12 nerve (subcostal nerve) runs below the 12th rib and supplies the muscles of the anterior abdominal wall and skin just below the costal margin.

Acute cholecystitis (Option A) typically presents with right upper quadrant pain that is often associated with nausea, vomiting, and fever.

  • The pain tends to be more constant and is aggravated by eating, particularly fatty foods. This patient lacks gastrointestinal symptoms and fever, making cholecystitis unlikely.

Appendicitis (Option C) typically starts with periumbilical pain that eventually migrates to the right lower quadrant.

  • It is also accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and fever, which this patient does not have. The pain in appendicitis is generally deep and constant, not related to movement.

Peptic ulcer disease (Option D) may present with epigastric pain and is often aggravated by food or empty stomach.

  • However, the pain tends to be dull and burning, rather than sharp and localized along the rib margin.
  • The absence of nausea, vomiting, and changes in appetite makes this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of a burning, aching sensation on the inner side of her left upper arm. She mentions that about two weeks ago she underwent mastectomy with axillary clearance. She describes the pain as localized along the inner part of the upper arm, extending from the axilla (armpit) to the medial elbow. The pain seems to worsen when she raises her arm. On physical examination, there is tenderness over the left axillary region and the medial upper arm, but no signs of swelling or lymphadenopathy. Based on the patient's history of breast surgery and the clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Intercostobrachial nerve injury

Explanation:

  • Intercostobrachial nerve injury is a well-known complication after breast surgery, particularly those involving the axillary region (such as axillary lymph node dissection or mastectomy).
  • This condition is referred to as post-mastectomy pain syndrome when associated with breast cancer surgery.
  • The pain may worsen with arm movements, and in some cases, hyperalgesia (heightened pain sensitivity) in the affected area is noted.
  • The intercostobrachial nerve arises from the second intercostal nerve (T2) and provides sensory innervation to the inner upper arm, the medial side of the axilla, and part of the chest. It is a purely sensory nerve and does not affect motor function.
  • Intercostobrachial nerve injury is a common complication following breast surgery—especially lumpectomy, mastectomy, or axillary lymph node dissection—due to the proximity of the nerve to the axillary region. During these procedures, the nerve can be cut, stretched, or irritated, leading to pain and sensory disturbances in its area of distribution.
  • The patient’s burning and aching pain localized to the inner upper arm after breast surgery, along with hyperalgesia (increased pain sensitivity) over the same area, strongly points to an injury to the intercostobrachial nerve.

Radial nerve injury (Option A) typically presents with symptoms like weakness and numbness in the posterior arm, forearm, and dorsal hand, not localized pain along the inner upper arm.

  • Additionally, motor weakness would be present in the arm, which is not the case here.

Cervical radiculopathy (Option B)(C7) usually causes pain, numbness, and weakness that radiates from the neck down to the hand, particularly affecting the middle finger and triceps muscle.

Thoracic outlet syndrome (Option D) can cause pain and numbness in the neck, shoulder, and upper arm due to compression of the brachial plexus, subclavian artery, or subclavian vein.

  • However, this syndrome usually presents with neurovascular symptoms (e.g., weakness, coldness, or swelling in the arm) and is less likely to cause isolated sensory symptoms.

questions.text:
Identify the structure marked as X in the image.



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Subclavian vein

 

Explanation:

The subclavian vein is a key vessel in the venous system that drains blood from the upper limb, the neck, and part of the chest. It is located in the thoracic region and plays a crucial role in returning deoxygenated blood to the heart.

1. Location and Course:

  • The subclavian vein is positioned deep to the clavicle (collarbone) and lies within the thoracic inlet, a narrow space between the neck and the chest.
  • It runs laterally and horizontally beneath the clavicle, crossing the first rib and passing anterior to the anterior scalene muscle.
  • It continues to run towards the right or left sternoclavicular joint, where it drains into the brachiocephalic vein on both sides (right and left).

2. Relations:

  • Posterior Relations:
    • The subclavian vein is located anterior to the subclavian artery.
    • The clavicle (collarbone) lies above the vein, and it is closely associated with the sternoclavicular joint and muscles like the pectoralis minor.
  • Anterior Relations:
    • The subclavian vein runs posterior to the anterior scalene muscle, which separates it from the subclavian artery.
    • The vein is also related to the first rib, which lies beneath it.
  • Medial Relations:
    • On the medial side, it is adjacent to the brachiocephalic vein.
  • Lateral Relations:
    • The vein continues laterally and joins the internal jugular vein to form the brachiocephalic vein.
    • The thoracic duct (on the left side) drains into the subclavian vein near the junction of the internal jugular vein.
  • The subclavian vein is larger and more anterior and superficial than the subclavian artery.

3. Anatomy:

  • Right subclavian vein: It drains into the right brachiocephalic vein.
  • Left subclavian vein: It drains into the left brachiocephalic vein.
  • Thoracic duct: The thoracic duct drains lymph from the left side of the body into the left subclavian vein near its junction with the internal jugular vein.

4. Clinical Relevance:

  • The subclavian vein is often used for central venous catheter insertion, central venous pressure monitoring.
  • Subclavian vein thrombosis (also known as Paget-Schroetter syndrome) can occur due to repetitive trauma, leading to clots, especially in athletes or individuals with certain anatomical predispositions.

questions.text: In a healthy individual at rest, which of the following is a primary muscle involved in expiration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) None of the above

 

Explanation:

Expiration is a passive process at rest due to elastic recoil of the lung and chest wall.

 

Type of Breathing

Muscles Involved

Process

Remarks

Quiet Expiration

Elastic recoil of chest wall and pulmonary alveoli

Passive

Mainly elastic recoil, aided by abdominal muscle tone

Forced Expiration

Abdominal muscles, Latissimus dorsi

Active

Strong contraction of abdominal muscles

 

The diaphragm (Option A) is primarily involved in inspiration.

 

External intercostal muscles (Option B) are used for inspiration.

 

Scalene muscles (Option C) are accessory muscles of inspiration and do not play a role in expiration.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles plays the primary role in quiet inspiration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) External intercostal muscles

Explanation:

The external intercostal muscles are the primary muscles responsible for quiet inspiration, aiding in the elevation of the ribs and expansion of the thoracic cavity.

 

Type of Breathing

Muscles Involved

Process

Remarks

Quiet Inspiration

Diaphragm

External Intercostal

(Option B)

Active

Increase in A-P, transverse, and vertical diameters

Forced Inspiration

Scalene (Option C )

Sternocleidomastoid (Option D )

Erector Spinae, Pectoral muscles, Trapezius, Levator Scapulae, Rhomboids

Active

Exaggerated movements, Scapulae elevated and fixed

 

Anterior abdominal wall muscles (Option A) and internal intercostal muscles are primarily involved in forced expiration.

 

Scalene muscles (Option C) and the sternocleidomastoid muscle (Option D) are accessory muscles that come into play during deep or labored inspiration but not during quiet inspiration.

questions.text: Which rib movements are responsible for increasing the anteroposterior diameter of the thoracic cavity during inspiration?

Correct Answer: A) Pump-handle movement of ribs 1-6

Explanation:

The pump-handle movement of the upper ribs (ribs 1-6) increases the anteroposterior (AP) diameter of the thoracic cavity during inspiration, elevating the sternum and ribs forward.

questions.text: The 2nd to 7th sternocostal joints are categorized as which type of joint?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Synovial

 

Explanation:

  • The second to seventh sternocostal joints are synovial joints.
  • These are the joints between the costal cartilages of the ribs and the sternum.

 

Thorax joints

Manubriosternal Joint:

  • It is between the manubrium and the body of the sternum.
  • It lies in the midline.
  • It is usually a symphysis

Xiphisternal joint:

  • It is between the xiphoid process and body of the sternum.
  • It is a symphysis type of joint. (Option B )

First sternocostal joint:

  • It is a type of synarthrosis (fibrous joint) (Option C )
  • It is inaccurately called synchondrosis. (Option D )

The second to seventh sternocostal joints:

  • It is a synovial type of joint. (Option A)
  • Mobile joints for free movements.
  • Helps in respiratory movements.

Interchondral joints:

  • Adjoining borders of the sixth to ninth costal cartilages articulate by apposition.
  • Each articulation is lined by a synovial membrane.

questions.text: The costal cartilages of which ribs attach directly to the sternum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1–7

 

Explanation:

The first seven pairs of ribs (ribs 1–7) are true ribs as they are directly attached to the sternum via their costal cartilages.

 

Ribs

 

True ribs

False ribs
  • Attach to the sternum directly.
  • AKA vertebrosternal ribs
  • Arise from the vertebra.
  • 1-7 are true ribs. (Option A)
  • Do not attach to the sternum directly. They are indirectly attached to the sternum through the costal margin.
  • Arise from the vertebra.
  • 8-12 are false ribs. (Option B ).
  • 8,9,10 ribs form the costal margin. (Option D ). AKA vertebrochondral ribs
  •  
  • 11,12 are floating ribs (They are not attached to the sternum at all). (Option C )

 

Costal groove:

  • It is situated along the lower part of the inner surface of a rib.
  • It contains the posterior intercostal vessels and intercostal nerve.
  • Pleural tap is done along upper border of lower rib to prevent injury to intercostal vessels and nerves.

questions.text: The pleura extends inferiorly to which rib at the midclavicular line in a normal adult?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 8th rib

 

Explanation:

The costodiaphragmatic line of pleural reflection passes laterally from the lower limit of its anterior margin, crossing the eighth rib in the midclavicular line.

 

Pleural markings

Anterior margin:

Right side

Left side

From the sternoclavicular joint vertically downwards to the midpoint of the xiphisternal joint (level of 6th costal cartilage). (Option A )

Same as right side except at the level of 4th costal cartilage it arches outwards and descends along the sternal margin up to the 6th costal cartilage. For cardiac notch.

 

Inferior margin (costodiaphragmatic line of pleural reflection):

From the lower limit of its anterior margin, it crosses

  • 8th rib in the midclavicular line (Option B)
  • 10th rib in the midaxillary line (Option C )
  • 12th rib at the lateral border of the sacrospinalis muscle (Option D )

 

Posterior margin:

Extends from 2 cm lateral to the 12th thoracic spine to 2 cm lateral to the 7th cervical spine.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with known dextrocardia comes for a routine checkup. Where would you expect to hear the loudest apex beat on physical examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Right 5th intercostal space

 

Explanation:

  • Dextrocardia is a congenital anomaly where the heart is placed on the right side of the thorax.
  • The apex beat is heard in the right fifth intercostal space to the right of the inferior end of the sternum.

 

Dextrocardia

  • It is a rare congenital anomaly in which the heart is located on the right side of the thoracic cavity.
  • Sometimes, the viscera of the abdomen and thorax including the heart are a mirror image of normal. This condition is called ‘situs inversus’.
  • The apex beat is heard in the right fifth intercostal space to the right of the inferior end of the sternum (Option B)
  • Kartagener syndrome (ciliary dyskinesia):
    • Chronic sinusitis
    • Bronchiectasis
    • Dextrocardia

questions.text: During bronchoscopy, the carina is an important landmark that separates the openings of the right and left main bronchi. Which of the following statements about the tracheal bifurcation is true?

choices.text: The left main bronchus is shorter and more vertical than the right
The right main bronchus is wider and more horizontal than the left
The left main bronchus is longer and more horizontal than the right
The right main bronchus is narrower and more vertical than the left

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The left main bronchus is longer and more horizontal than the right

 

Explanation: The right main bronchus is approximately 2.5 cm long, and is wider, shorter, and more vertical than the left.

 

Bifurcation of trachea

  • Level of bifurcation: T5–T6 intervertebral disc
  • The angle between left and right principal bronchus - 70⁰
  • Bifurcates into left and right main (principal) bronchus
  • Right main bronchus
    • Shorter in length (Option C)
    • Wider lumen
    • More vertical (Option C)
    • Inhaled foreign bodies and aspiration occurs at the right main bronchus more often than the left

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient is admitted to the hospital after undergoing elective surgery. Post-anesthesia, he is found to be unconscious and placed in a supine position for monitoring. The healthcare team is concerned about the risk of aspiration due to his current state. Which location is most likely to collect aspirated material in this patient?

choices.text: Anterior Basal BPS of the right lower lobe
Posterior BPS of the right upper lobe
Apical Basal BPS of the right lower lobe
Lateral BPS of the right middle lobe

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Apical Basal BPS of the right lower lobe

 

Explanation:

  • The Apical Basal BPS of the right lower lobe is the most likely site for aspirated material in a supine, unconscious patient
  • Due to its anatomical position and tendency to collect fluids.
  • Other segments, while dependent, are less favorable for aspiration accumulation. (Option A, B, and D )

 

 

Right Lung:

  • Superior Lobe:
    • S1: Apical
    • S2: Posterior
    • S3: Anterior
  • Middle Lobe:
    • S4: Lateral
    • S5: Medial
  • Inferior Lobe:
    • S6: Superior (Apical)
    • S7: Medial Basal
    • S8: Anterior Basal
    • S9: Lateral Basal
    • S10: Posterior Basal

 

Most Dependent Location:

  • Superior segment of right lower lobe

 

Aspiration Risk:

  • Supine posture.
  • Coma and unconscious patients (e.g., post-anesthesia).

Collection Sites:

  • Posterior BPS of the right upper lobe.
  • Apical Basal BPS of the right lower lobe.

Preferred Collection Site:

  • Apical Basal BPS of the right lower lobe > Posterior BPS of the right upper lobe.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female undergoes right lower lobe resection for a tumor. Which statement about bronchopulmonary segments is true?

choices.text: Each segment shares a bronchus with adjacent segments.
Segments are supplied by segmental arteries and share venous drainage.
Each segment has independent arterial and venous supplies.
The shape is pyramidal with the base at the hilum.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Segments are supplied by segmental arteries and share venous drainage.

 

Explanation:

Bronchopulmonary Segments

 

Features:

  • Well-defined anatomical segments of the lung, each aerated by a tertiary (segmental) bronchus.
  • Each segment has its own arterial supply, but shares venous drainage with adjacent segments. (Option B) (Option C )

 

  • Anatomical, Functional, and Surgical Units: Serve as distinct sectors of the lung.
  • Aerosol Supply: Each segment is supplied by a tertiary (segmental) bronchus. (Option A )
  • Shape: Pyramidal, with the apex oriented towards the root of the lung. (Option D )
  • Vascular and Nerve Supply: Contains a segmental bronchus, segmental artery, autonomic nerves, and lymph vessels.
  • Venous Drainage: Segmental venules are located in the connective tissue between adjacent segments.
  • Surgical Resection: Surgeons isolate segments by working along the segmental veins during resection procedures.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with a persistent cough and shortness of breath. A chest X-ray shows a mass in the right lung. The attending physician is reviewing the anatomical structures relevant to potential surgical intervention. Which of the following statements about the anatomy of the right and left lungs is correct?

choices.text: The right superior pulmonary vein is located posteriorly to the bronchus.
The eparterial bronchus in the right lung is found above the pulmonary artery.
The most superior structure of the left lung hilum is the Pulmonary vein.
The bronchus on the left side is shorter in length compared to the right bronchus.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The eparterial bronchus in the right lung is found above the pulmonary artery

 

Explanation:

 

  • In the right lung, the eparterial bronchus is anatomically located superior to the right pulmonary artery.
  • This unique positioning is important for surgical considerations.

Medial surface of the Lung

  • Right Lung:
    • Posterior Region: Bronchus is present.
    • Anterior Region:
      • Right superior pulmonary vein (Option A)
      • Right inferior pulmonary vein
    • Pulmonary Artery: More superior
    • Eparterial Bronchus: Present above the artery.
    • Hyparterial Bronchus: Present below the artery.
  • Left Lung:
    • Posterior Region: Bronchus is present.
    • Anterior Region:
      • Left superior pulmonary vein
      • Left inferior pulmonary vein
    • Pulmonary Artery: More superior in the superior region.

Mnemonic (From Superior to Inferior)

  • Atal Bihari Vajpayee: (Option C)
    • A: Arteries
    • B: Bronchus
    • V: Veins

NB:

  • The eparterial bronchus is unique to the right lung's superior region.
  • The right bronchus is shorter in length compared to the left (Option D)
